# 3.1. Exercises

## True or False: Many Distributions

<div id='mcq1'></div> 
<script>
    generateQuiz(
        'mcq1', 
        'True or False',  
        'Using a bar plot to display a statistic like the mean, is an effective way to compare quantitative dataframe columns.', 
        { 
        'True': 'This hinders us from seeing any variation in the data and can be problematic and cause us to draw incorrect conclusions.',
        'False': ''
        },
        'False',  
    );
</script>

<div id='mcq2'></div> 
<script>
    generateQuiz(
        'mcq2',
        'True or False',
        'We can sort boxplots by their median value within an Altair plot by specifying sort=‘median’.',
        {
        'True': 'We have to first use `pandas` to sort the categorical dataframe column’s mean values outside of the `alt.Chart()`.',
        'False': 'You remembered that we must do this first before making the plot!'
        },
        'False',
    );
</script>

## Why and How to Compare Multiple Distributions

<div id='mcq3'></div> 
<script>
    generateQuiz(
        'mcq3',
        'Question 1',
        'When comparing the value counts of certain dataframe columns, why can it be extremely difficult to obtain meaningful insights from density plots such as the one below?',
        {
        'There are too many records.': 'Having a lot of observations has no impact on a density plot.',
        'The majority of the observations lie on the left side of the plot making the values and genres difficult to observe.': '',
        'There are too many columns being plotted.': 'We are only plotting one column from a dataframe so this should not matter.',
        'The x-axis tend to display too many values without reason.': 'If our plot includes the axis to the length shown, there are records for the values but they are so close to 0, that they cannot be identified.'
        },
        'The majority of the observations lie on the left side of the plot making the values and genres difficult to observe.',
    );
</script>

## Boxplots and Penguins


**Instructions:**    
Be patient when running a coding exercise for the first time, it can take a few minutes. 

**When you see `____` in a coding exercise, replace it with what you assume to be the correct code. Run the code to see if you obtain the desired output
and submit it to validate if you were correct.**


In the last few slides, we were faceting and using colour channels to compare the body mass of different species of penguins. Let's explore this but this time using a boxplot!


```{pyodide}
import altair as alt
import pandas as pd

penguins_df = pd.read_csv('data/penguins.csv')
penguins_df.info()
```

**Tasks:**

Fill in the blanks in the code below so that the following gets accomplished.

- Use the data source `penguins_df` to make **boxplots** for the body mass values among the different penguin species.
- Make sure to give it an appropriate title and set the plot dimensions to a height of 200 and a width of 400.
- Remember to assign the `species` to the y-axis and the `body_mass_g` to the y-axis since we want to read the labels easily as we learned in the previous module.

```{pyodide}
#| setup: true
#| exercise: boxplot

import altair as alt
import pandas as pd
from utils import assert_chart_equal 
def remove_keys_inplace(spec, keys):
    if isinstance(spec, dict):
        for key in list(spec.keys()):
            if key in keys:
                del spec[key]
            else:
                remove_keys_inplace(spec[key], keys)
    elif isinstance(spec, list):
        for item in spec:
            remove_keys_inplace(item, keys)

penguins_df = pd.read_csv('data/penguins.csv')
```

```{pyodide}
#| exercise: boxplot
mass_boxplot = alt.Chart(___).___().encode(
    alt.X(___),
    alt.Y(___)).properties(
        ___, ___)

mass_boxplot
```

```{pyodide}
#| exercise: boxplot
#| check: true

solution = alt.Chart(penguins_df).mark_boxplot().encode(
    alt.X('body_mass_g', title='Mass (grams)'),
    alt.Y('species', title='Species')).properties(
         title='Body mass among penguin species', height=200, width=400)

solution_dict = solution.to_dict()
result_dict = result.to_dict()

remove_keys_inplace(solution_dict, {"opacity", "title"})
remove_keys_inplace(result_dict, {"opacity", "title"})

assert_chart_equal(solution_dict, result_dict)
```
